text: When an inner situation is not made conscious, it appears outside as fate.

text: Through pride we are ever deceiving ourselves. But deep down below the surface of the average conscience a still, small voice says to us, something is out of tune.

text: Children are educated by what the grown-up is and not by his talk.

text: Healing proceeds from the depths to the heights.

text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.

text: Even a happy life cannot be without a measure of darkness, and the word happy would lose its meaning if it were not balanced by sadness. It is far better take things as they come along with patience and equanimity.

text: Whenever we give up, leave behind, and forget too much, there is always the danger that the things we have neglected will return with added force.

text: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your heart. Who looks outside, dreams. Who looks inside, awakens.

text: The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases.

text: It all depends on how we look at things, and not how they are in themselves.

text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.

text: A particular beautiful woman is a source of terror. As a rule, a beautiful woman is a terrible disappointment.

text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.

text: The separation of psychology from the premises of biology is purely artificial, because the human psyche lives in indissoluble union with the body.

text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.

text: Emotion is the chief source of all becoming-conscious. There can be no transforming of darkness into light and of apathy into movement without emotion.
author: Carl Jung

text: aging people should know that their lives are not mounting and unfolding but that an inexorable inner process forces the contraction of life. For a young person it is almost a sin and certainly a danger to be too much occupied with himself; but for the aging person it is a duty and a necessity to give serious attention to himself.

text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances. If there is any reaction, both are transformed.

text: The pendulum of the mind alternates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.

text: We cannot change anything until we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.

text: The angels are a strange genus, they are precisely what they are and cannot be anything else. They are themselves soul-less beings who represent nothing but the thoughts and intuitions of their Lord.

text: The most intense conflicts, if overcome, leave behind a sense of security and calm that is not easily disturbed. It is just these intense conflicts and their conflagration which are needed to produce valuable and lasting results.

text: One looks back with appreciation to the brilliant teachers, but with gratitude to those who touched our human feelings. The curriculum is so much necessary raw material, but warmth is the vital element for the growing plant and for the soul of the child.

text: Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.

text: We deem those happy who from the experience of life have learnt to bear its ills without being overcome by them.

text: Without this playing with fantasy no creative work has ever yet come to birth. The debt we owe to the play of the imagination is incalculable.
author: Carl Jung

text: All the works of man have their origin in creative fantasy. What right have we then to depreciate imagination.

text: An understanding heart is everything in a teacher, and cannot be esteemed highly enough.

text: Protection and security are only valuable if they do not cramp life excessively.

text: Enchantment is the oldest form of medicine.

text: A human being would certainly not grow to be seventy or eighty years old if this longevity had no meaning for the species. The afternoon of human life must also have a significance of its own and cannot be merely a pitiful appendage to life's morning.

text: Gnosticism was stamped out completely and its remnants are so badly mangled that special study is needed to get any insight at all into its inner meaning.
author: Carl Jung

text: Grounded in the natural philosophy of the Middle Ages, alchemy formed a bridge: on the one hand into the past, to Gnosticism, and on the other into the future, to the modern psychology of the unconscious.
author: Carl Jung

text: It is astounding that man, the instigator, inventor and vehicle of all these developments, the originator of all judgements and decisions and the planner of the future, must make himself such a quantitÃ© negligeable.

text: Primitive superstition lies just below the surface of even the most tough-minded individuals, and it is precisely those who most fight against it who are the first to succumb to its suggestive effects.

text: Normality is a fine ideal for those who have no imagination.

text: Those who look outside, dream. Those who look inside, awaken.

text: Resistance to the organized mass can be effected only by the man who is as well organized in his individuality as the mass itself.

text: Science has destroyed even the refuge of the inner life.

text: We are born at a given moment, in a given place and, like vintage years of wine, we have the qualities of the year and of the season of which we are born. Astrology does not lay claim to anything more.

text: The unexpected and the incredible belong in this world. Only then is life whole.

text: Every true and deep love is a sacrifice.

text: Everything psychic is pregnant with the future.

text: The psychic depths are nature, and nature is creative life.

text: Every psychic advance of man arises from the suffering of the soul.

text: What usually has the strongest psychic effect on the child is the life which the parents have not lived.

text: We are a psychic process which we do not control, or only partly direct. Consequently, we cannot have any final judgment about ourselves or our lives.

text: I don't aspire to be a good man. I aspire to be a whole man.

text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.

text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.

text: There is no light without shadow, and no psychic wholeness without imperfection.

text: No field could thrive if we assumed that the oats we sowed were wheat, nor could our dog thrive if we took it to be a camel, and so it is unfair to our friends and unfair to ourselves to assume that we can be supermen.

text: We cannot change anything unless we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.
author: Carl Jung

text: I was frequently so wrought up that I had to do certain yoga exercises in order to hold my emotions in check. But since it was my purpose to know what was going on within myself, I would do these exercises only until I had calmed myself enough to resume my work with the unconscious. As soon as I had the feeling that I was myself again, I abandoned this restraint upon the emotions and allowed the images and inner voices to speak afresh. The Indian, on the other hand, does yoga exercises in order to obliterate completely the multitude of psychic contents and images.
author: Carl Jung

text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances; if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
author: Carl Jung

text: We understand the ego as the complex factor to which all conscious contents are related. It forms, as it were, the centre of the field of consciousness; and, in so far as this comprises the empirical personality, the ego is the subject of all personal acts of consciousness. The relation of a psychic content to the ego forms the criterion of its consciousness, for no content can be conscious until it is represented to a subject.
author: Carl Jung

text: In actual life, it requires the greatest discipline to be simple, and the acceptance of oneself is the essence of the moral problem and the epitome of a whole outlook upon life.
author: Carl Jung

text: The man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
author: Carl Jung

text: If meaninglessness were absolutely preponderant, the meaningless ends of life would vanish to an increasing degree with each step in our development. But that is— or seems to me— not the case. Probably, as in all metaphysical questions, both are true: Life is- or has-meaning and meaninglessness.
author: Carl Jung
